citeinfo.origin: Center for Applied Spatial Ecology, NMCFWRU, NMSU
citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Reptile Biodiversity Ecosystem Services Metrics by 12-digit HUC for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract:
This EnviroAtlas dataset contains biodiversity metrics reflecting ecosystem services or other aspects of biodiversity for reptile species, based on the number of reptile species as measured by predicted habitat present within a pixel. These metrics were created from grouping national level single species habitat models created by the USGS Gap Analysis Program into smaller ecologically based, phylogeny based, or stakeholder suggested composites.
The dataset includes reptile species richness metrics for all reptile species, lizards, snakes, turtles, poisonous reptiles, Natureserve-listed G1,G2, and G3 reptile species, and reptile species listed by IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature), PARC (Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation) and SWPARC (Southwest Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation).
This dataset was produced by a joint effort of New Mexico State University, US EPA, and USGS to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose:
This data could be used in conjunction with other biodiversity data or ecosystem service data to identify concordance and discordance between metrics. Areas of concordance highlight the similarity between the two metrics. Areas of discordance highlight dissimilar areas, but must then be reviewed to understand why the dissimilarity occurs.
Reptile Species Richness can be indicative of recreational opportunities or aesthetic qualities. Ecosystem services, i.e., services provided to humans from ecological systems have become a key issue of this century in resource management, conservation planning, and environmental decision analysis. Mapping and quantifying ecosystem services have become strategic national interests for integrating ecology with economics to help understand the effects of human policies and actions and their subsequent impacts on both ecosystem function and human well-being. Some aspects of biodiversity are valued by humans in varied ways, and thus are important to include in any assessment that seeks to identify and quantify the benefits of ecosystems to humans. Some biodiversity metrics clearly reflect ecosystem services (e.g., abundance and diversity of harvestable species), whereas others may reflect indirect and difficult to quantify relationships to services (e.g., relevance of species diversity to ecosystem resilience, cultural and aesthetic values). Wildlife habitat has been modeled at broad spatial scales and can be used to map a number of biodiversity metrics
The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://epa.gov/geospatial/policies.html

procstep.procdesc: Individual habitat models obtained from National Gap Analysis Program Office
Species lists for biodiversity metrics were created
Species models for each list were combined and the sum of species with potential habitat was calculated using ArcGIS cell statistics
Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) for SWPARC listed reptiles was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area.

enttyp.enttypd: Reptile Biodiversity Metrics for the US

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: 12-digit HUC
The maximum number of Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The Reptile All Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of lizard species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of lizard species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Lizard Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of snake species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of snake species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Snake Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of turtle species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of turtle species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The turtle Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of G1,G2, and G3 Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of G1,G2, and G3 Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) of G1,G2, and G3 reptiles was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of IUCN listed Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of IUCN listed Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) OF IUCN listed Reptiles was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of PARC listed Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of PARC listed Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.

Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) of PARC listed reptile species was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of poisonous Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of poisonous Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) for poisonous reptiles was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).
The maximum number of SWPARC listed Reptile species in any one pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
The mean number of SWPARC listed Reptile species per pixel for each 12-digit HUC over the contiguous US.
Normalized Index of Biodiversity (NIB) for SWPARC listed reptiles was calculated by dividing the mean species richness value of each HUC by the maximum value for the study area (the contiguous US).

overview.eaover:
This dataset includes the maximum, mean, and normalized index of biodiversity for the following:
*All reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *Lizard species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *Snake species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *Turtle species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *Natureserve listed G1,G2, and G3 Reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *All IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) listed Reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US.Includes CR,DD, EN, NT and VU. *All PARC (Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation) listed Reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *All poisonous Reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US. *All SWPARC (Southwest Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation) listed Reptile species modeled by USGS GAP across the contiguous US.
A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps. For more information about EnviroAtlas data go to https://enviroatlas.epa.gov/EnviroAtlas/DataFactSheets/index.html.
